prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: IRAS15194: Band 3, Tuning 1
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Tuning 1: Band 3 spectral survey of IRAS15194-5115

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: One of the goals is to determine the size and thickness of the shells (for those molecules molecules that are distributed in shells), and a number of velocity resolution elements (at least 10) over the line is necessary to do this.
The sizes of the emission regions are expected to be about 1"-7" in shapes of disks or annular structures (depending on molecule) at the systemic velocity of the object.

Obtaining a sensitivity of about 3 mJy/beam rms (with a spectral resolution of 0.9 MHz, equivalent to a velocity resolution of about 3 km/s), will allow us to detect and image the weaker lines. Note that the IRAS 15194 lines are 43 km/s wide, making it possible to further smooth the spectra by a factor of 2-3 for detection experiments
With an rms flux of 3 mJy/beam, the weakest lines we aim to detect (without imaging and with spectral smoothing) have a flux density of about 10 mJy. The weakest lines we aim to image will have a flux of about 15 mJy/beam (5 sigma) if the emission is not extended, and 375 mJy (5 sigma/beam) if the emission has an annular structure with e.g.an outer diameter of 7"and inner diameter of 2.5" (i.e. an area of 25 square arcsec). The weakest lines in the SEST spectrum in Woods et al. (2003) have a flux of about 375 mJy.

The number of spws cannot be reduced since all spws are needed to perform the survey in Band 3. Spectral average of a factor 2 was applied to reduce the data rate since this still gives enough velocity resolution elements over the line.

The weakest lines in the SEST spectrum in Woods et al. (2003) have a flux of about 375 mJy.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: IRAS07454: Band 3, Tuning 1
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Tuning 1: Band 3 spectral survey of IRAS07454

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: One of the goals is to determine the size and thickness of the shells (for those molecules molecules that are distributed in shells), and a number of velocity resolution elements (in this case 8) over the line is necessary to do this.
The sizes of the emission regions are expected to be about 1"-7" in shapes of disks or annular structures (depending on molecule) at the systemic velocity of the object.

Obtaining a sensitivity of about 3 mJy/beam rms (with a spectral resolution of 0.9 MHz, equivalent to a velocity resolution of about 3 km/s), will allow us to detect and image the weaker lines. Note that the IRAS 07454 lines are 26 km/s wide, making it possible to further smooth the spectra by a factor of 2-3 for detection experiments
With an rms flux of 3 mJy/beam, the weakest lines we aim to detect (without imaging and with spectral smoothing) have a flux density of about 10 mJy. The weakest lines we aim to image will have a flux of about 15 mJy/beam (5 sigma) if the emission is not extended, and 375 mJy (5 sigma/beam) if the emission has an annular structure with e.g.an outer diameter of 7"and inner diameter of 2.5" (i.e. an area of 25 square arcsec). The weakest lines in the SEST spectrum in Woods et al. (2003) have a flux of about 375 mJy.

The project depends on being able to image the object in spectral channels (see correlator setup justification). Therefore it is not possible to reduce the spectral resolution by spectral averaging. The number of spws cannot be reduced since all spws are needed to perform the spectral scan.

The sizes of the emission regions are expected to be about 1"-7" in shapes of disks or annular structures (depending on molecule) at the systemic velocity of the object.

Obtaining a sensitivity of about 3 mJy/beam rms (with a spectral resolution of 0.9 MHz, equivalent to a velocity resolution of about 3 km/s), will allow us to detect and image the weaker lines. Note that the AFGL3068 lines are 28 km/s wide, making it possible to further smooth the spectra by a factor of 2-3 for detection experiments
With an rms flux of 3 mJy/beam, the weakest lines we aim to detect (without imaging and with spectral smoothing) have a flux density of about 10 mJy. The weakest lines we aim to image will have a flux of about 15 mJy/beam (5 sigma) if the emission is not extended, and 375 mJy (5 sigma/beam) if the emission has an annular structure with e.g.an outer diameter of 7"and inner diameter of 2.5" (i.e. an area of 25 square arcsec). The weakest lines in the SEST spectrum in Woods et al. (2003) have a flux of about 375 mJy.

The project depends on being able to image the object in spectral channels (see correlator setup justification). Therefore it is not possible to reduce the spectral resolution by spectral averaging. The number of spws cannot be reduced since all spws are needed to perform the spectral scan.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: AFGL3068: Band 3, Tuning 5
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Tuning 4: Band 3 spectral survey of IRAS15194-5115

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: One of the goals is to determine the size and thickness of the shells (for those molecules molecules that are distributed in shells), and a number of velocity resolution elements (in this case 9) over the line is necessary to do this.
The sizes of the emission regions are expected to be about 1"-7" in shapes of disks or annular structures (depending on molecule) at the systemic velocity of the object.

Obtaining a sensitivity of about 3 mJy/beam rms (with a spectral resolution of 0.9 MHz, equivalent to a velocity resolution of about 3 km/s), will allow us to detect and image the weaker lines. Note that the AFGL3068 lines are 28 km/s wide, making it possible to further smooth the spectra by a factor of 2-3 for detection experiments
With an rms flux of 3 mJy/beam, the weakest lines we aim to detect (without imaging and with spectral smoothing) have a flux density of about 10 mJy. The weakest lines we aim to image will have a flux of about 15 mJy/beam (5 sigma) if the emission is not extended, and 375 mJy (5 sigma/beam) if the emission has an annular structure with e.g.an outer diameter of 7"and inner diameter of 2.5" (i.e. an area of 25 square arcsec). The weakest lines in the SEST spectrum in Woods et al. (2003) have a flux of about 375 mJy.

The project depends on being able to image the object in spectral channels (see correlator setup justification). Therefore it is not possible to reduce the spectral resolution by spectral averaging. The number of spws cannot be reduced since all spws are needed to perform the spectral scan.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract:
To date, most of our knowledge on circumstellar chemistry of carbon-rich envelopes is based on the results obtained towards a single object, IRC+10216. In order to obtain a more general knowledge of the chemistry in these envelopes we intend to use ALMA to perform a spectral line survey in the 3 mm band of a sample of four carbon stars. Single dish spectral line surveys in the 3mm band have been performed of all stars in the sample, and shows there are more than an order of magnitude variation in abundances of some of the molecular species (Woods et al. 1993). The abundance calculations in Woods et al., however, suffered from the assumption that the emitting regions had the same morphology and size as in IRC+10216. To determine accurate molecular abundances, we need the spatial information of the emitting regions in the objects in the sample.
The ALMA data will be used as input for models developed by members of the team to determine the physical characteristics and chemistry of the circumstellar envelopes of the objects in our sample.
This is a resubmission of a Cycle 2 filler project. If it is (partly) observed during Cycle 2, the Cycle 3 project can be (descoped) cancelled.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:previousProposals: This proposal is a resubmission of 2013.1.00070.S
